question: Compare the two photographs and say why the people might have decided to spend their time in these ways.

default.text: Both photos show people enjoying nature. The first picture is of a beautiful beach, and the second one shows someone hiking in the mountains. In both cases, people have chosen to spend time outside in really nice places.

But they're very different activities. The beach is all about relaxing - you just sit there and chill out. The mountain hiking is completely different - it's active and you need to be quite fit. The beach is easy to get to, but going up a mountain needs proper planning.

So why did they choose these activities? I think the people at the beach probably wanted to escape from their busy lives and just relax. Maybe they were feeling stressed and needed somewhere quiet and peaceful. The mountain hiker is different - they probably chose this because they like a challenge. Some people prefer doing something active where they push themselves. Plus, the views from the top of a mountain are amazing - that's a pretty good reason to climb up there!

question: Compare the two photographs and say how the people might be feeling in these situations.

default.text: Both photos show people in places with lots of other people around. The first one shows a busy city street at night with crowds everywhere. The second photo shows students working together in a library. In both situations, people are sharing the same space.

But the social situations are totally different. In the city, nobody really knows each other - it's just random people walking past. It's quite impersonal. But the students are clearly friends working together. They're talking and helping each other. The city is about being alone even though you're with people, but the library is about real connection.

default.text: How might people be feeling? In the busy city, I think it's mixed. Some people probably feel excited by all the lights and energy. But others might feel overwhelmed or even lonely even though there are so many people around. Everyone's just going somewhere and not really connecting. The students probably feel quite different - maybe a bit stressed about their work, but they also feel supported because they have friends there. Studying in a group makes you feel less alone when things are difficult.

Another key difference is that the city feels anonymous and impersonal, whereas the study group represents genuine social bonds.

question: Compare the two photographs and say why the people might have chosen to spend their time in these ways.

default.text: Both photos show people having fun and relaxing. In the first one, people are watching a movie at the cinema. In the second picture, a family is playing board games at home. In both cases, people are choosing entertainment to enjoy their free time.

But they're quite different types of entertainment. The cinema is a public place where you watch something that's been made for you. You're passive - you just sit and watch. Board games at home are totally different - you're active and you have to think and make decisions. Also, at the cinema you're with strangers, while board games are usually with family or close friends.

So why might they have chosen these? I think people go to the cinema because they want to escape into a story and forget about their own lives for a couple of hours. The big screen and sound system make it really immersive. It's a special experience you can't get at home. The family playing board games probably chose this because they wanted to spend quality time together. Board games make you interact and talk with each other. Plus it's much cheaper than going out, and you can pause whenever you want.

question: Compare the two photographs and say what might be enjoyable or frustrating about shopping in these places.

default.text: Both photos show places where people go shopping. The first one is a big modern shopping mall with lots of stores. The second picture shows a local market with individual stalls. In both situations, people are buying things they need or want.

But the shopping experiences are completely different. The mall is modern, clean, and organized with big chain stores. Everything has a fixed price and you can use your card. The market is much more traditional and authentic. It looks a bit messy and chaotic, with fresh produce and small vendors. You probably need cash and might have to bargain over prices.

vocabulary.phrase: But the shopping experiences are completely different

default.text: What might be enjoyable or frustrating? In the mall, the good thing is it's convenient - everything's in one place, it's air-conditioned, and it's easy to find what you want. But it can feel impersonal and crowded, plus everything is quite expensive. At the market, the enjoyable part is the atmosphere - it's lively and you get fresh, local products. You can talk to the vendors and get a better deal. But it might be frustrating if it's too hot, crowded, or if you don't speak the language well enough to negotiate.

alternative1.text: These two pictures both show shopping environments. The first depicts a modern shopping mall with multiple stores, while the second shows a traditional outdoor market. What they have in common is that both are places where consumers purchase goods.

However, the shopping experiences are very different. While the mall is modern and climate-controlled with chain retailers, the market is traditional and open-air with independent vendors. Another difference is that malls have fixed prices, whereas markets often involve price negotiation.

vocabulary.phrase: However, the shopping experiences are very different

alternative1.text: As for what's enjoyable or frustrating, I'd say the mall offers convenience - everything in one location, comfortable climate, and easy transactions. However, it could feel impersonal and prices tend to be higher. The market, on the other hand, provides atmosphere and cultural experience. You might enjoy the fresh products and bargaining opportunities. Perhaps the frustrations would be the heat, crowds, or language barriers when negotiating prices.

vocabulary.phrase: As for what's enjoyable or frustrating

alternative2.text: In both photographs we can see retail environments where shopping takes place. The first shows a contemporary shopping center, while the second depicts a traditional market setting. One thing both places have in common is that they serve as commercial spaces for buying and selling goods.

alternative2.text: On the other hand, these retail environments differ significantly. The mall represents organized, standardized shopping, whereas the market embodies traditional, informal commerce. It seems to me that another key difference is pricing - malls use fixed prices, while markets typically involve negotiation.

Regarding what might be enjoyable or frustrating, I imagine mall shoppers appreciate the convenience and comfort - centralized location, air conditioning, and straightforward purchasing. They might find it frustrating that it feels somewhat impersonal and prices are generally higher. As for the market, I reckon the enjoyable aspects would be the vibrant atmosphere and fresh, local products. It's possible that bargaining adds to the experience. question: Compare the two photographs and say what the benefits might be of exercising in these different ways.

default.text: Both photos show people exercising and being active. In the first one, someone is working out at a gym using machines. In the second photo, people are doing yoga outside in a park. In both cases, people are taking care of their health and fitness.

But they're very different types of exercise. The gym workout is indoors and uses equipment - it's probably focused on building strength or losing weight. It looks intense and individual. The outdoor yoga is gentle and relaxing, done in nature with a group. One is about pushing your body hard, while the other is about flexibility and calmness.

So what are the benefits? The gym is great for specific fitness goals - you can target certain muscles, track your progress, and work out whatever the weather. Plus there's usually a trainer who can help you. But it can be expensive and a bit boring. Outdoor yoga gives you fresh air and connection with nature, which is really good for mental health. It's also more social - you're part of a class. The downside is you can't do it when it's raining, and it might not give you the intense workout some people want.

alternative1.text: These two pictures both show people engaged in physical exercise. The first depicts gym training with equipment, while the second shows outdoor yoga in a park. What they have in common is that both individuals are working on their physical fitness and wellbeing.

However, the exercise styles are quite different. While gym training is high-intensity and equipment-based, yoga is gentle and focuses on flexibility. Another difference is that the gym is indoors and individual, whereas yoga takes place outdoors in a group setting.

vocabulary.phrase: However, the exercise styles are quite different

alternative1.text: As for the benefits, I'd say gym training allows for targeted muscle development and measurable progress regardless of weather. Perhaps the advantage is having professional guidance available. However, it could be expensive and repetitive. Outdoor yoga, on the other hand, offers mental health benefits through nature connection and fresh air. I imagine the group atmosphere is motivating. The limitation might be weather dependence and lower cardiovascular intensity.

alternative2.text: In both photographs we can see people doing physical exercise. The first shows gym-based strength training, while the second depicts outdoor yoga practice. One thing both activities share is their focus on improving physical health and fitness.

vocabulary.phrase: In both photographs we can see

alternative2.text: On the other hand, the approaches to fitness are very different. The gym represents intensive, equipment-based training in a controlled environment, whereas yoga embodies gentle, mindful movement in natural surroundings. It seems to me that the social element also differs - gym work appears solitary, while yoga is clearly a group activity.

Regarding the benefits, I imagine gym training offers targeted physical results and weather independence. Gym-goers might appreciate the ability to track progress and receive expert instruction. However, it could be costly and monotonous. As for outdoor yoga, I reckon the main benefits would be psychological - fresh air, nature exposure, and stress reduction. It's possible that the community aspect provides motivation. What might be limiting, though, is the weather dependency and potentially insufficient intensity for those seeking vigorous exercise.

The street food is much more casual and quick - you just grab something and eat it standing up or walking around. One is a full meal experience, while the other is more like a snack on the go.
